awd_titl_txt: Effect of Variability on Fall Risk and Energetic Cost in Biped Walking
awd_abstract_narration:
When both people and biped robots walk, they move through approximately the same motion at every step, but not exactly the same motion. The differences in their motions appear to contribute to the risk of falling. The exact relationship between this variability (differences in motion) and falling events is unknown. Variability may also affect how much energy is required to walk but again the relationship between variability and energy required is unknown. The robustness is defined as achieving a reduced risk of falling and also requiring minimum energy in spite of the presence of variability. This project will determine which aspects of variability decrease robustness. The project will also investigate if increasing the duration of the double support period of gait (the period when both feet are on the ground) increases robustness. The research will lead to a diagnostic tool to determine likelihood of biped falling. This tool can provide clinicians with valuable insights into how changes in walking gaits affect the fall risk. This work will also lead to improved capabilities for biped robots, which in turn will significantly increase their utility. The fall risk diagnostic tool will be adapted into an experimental activity for middle and high schoolers to introduce the concepts of diagnostics and estimation. The research is expected to broaden participation by strengthening the connection between engineering and people's wellbeing. 

The project will involve theoretical- and simulation-based work that will consider how a novel combination of the double support controller and joint variability alters robustness. This study will develop multiple double support controllers and prove both theoretically and through simulation that increasing the duration of the double support period increases robustness. Different double support control formulations will be compared, and the formulation that results in the most robust gait will be determined. Using simulations, the role of the magnitude, frequency, and continuity in joint variability at each joint will be analyzed by systematically altering the modeled variability and simulating the gait until the model falls. Because variability at one joint is likely to interact with variability at other joints, it will be altered using a fractional factorial experimental design paradigm. This study will use the simulations to determine which easily measurable gait characteristics are correlated with robustness. These measurements will be combined to form a diagnostic tool that can accurately predict gait robustness using a computationally realistic number of steps. The diagnostic tool will be used to design new gaits that are optimized for robustness.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this research was to analyze how the double-support period (the period when both feet are on the ground) and joint motion variability in bipedal walking alters fall risk. This was then used to develop a diagnostic tool to determine how likely a biped is to fall. If the diagnostic tool was accurate, it could eventually provide clinicians with currently unavailable objective insights into how changes in walking gaits affect fall risk. This would allow clinicians to incorporate the possibility for elevated fall risk into the dialog about fall prevention with their patients. This work could also lead to improved capabilities for biped robots, which in turn would significantly increase their utility.

 When both people and two-legged robots walk, they move through approximately the same motion every step, but not exactly the same motion. This variability in movement appears to be correlated with fall risk, although the exact relationship between variability and falling was unknown. Using simulations of bipeds walking, this work determined that the distance the joint angle changed from the expected angle increased fall risk the most. The timing of the variability did not matter as much.

 We performed other simulation work to investigate how healthy people handle the variability.  To do so, we found mathematical equations that described how people controlled their legs. We found three different sets of equations using different mathematical methods. The simplest equations produced the most accurate results. This suggests that the human brain may control walking using a very simple method.

 This work also examined if increasing the duration of the double support period of gait decreased fall risk. Most previous research has assumed that a longer double support period would increase stability because having two feet on the ground keeps the hips more directly over the feet. We conducted experiments in which we asked people to change how long they spent on two feet while walking. Most people could easily decrease how long they spent on two feet but not increase it. This suggests that most people naturally walk with the longest easily achievable double support duration. We then performed simulation work in which the model walked with an instantaneous double support period and a finite-time double support period. Surprisingly, we found that both walking motions were equally stable and that a longer double support period did not automatically increase stability.

 Using these simulations, we then developed a diagnostic tool to determine how likely a biped was to fall. Because we could control everything about the simulations, this gave us a best-case scenario for how accurate the diagnostic tool could be. As expected, we showed that combining multiple aspects about the walking better predicted fall risk than using one aspect. We also showed that predicting fall risk from many steps was more accurate than only using data from a few steps. Unfortunately, even the best version of the diagnostic tool was only moderately accurate.

 Because walking is easily accessible and familiar to students, we developed a workshop for teachers about this work. One of the key concepts we discussed was how to convert a real-world situation (walking) into a model. We also discussed how we used polynomials in this research. By applying engineering to real-work situations, this workshop could broaden participation by demonstrating how engineering is not just about machines and how it can be used to help people.
